children.text: Select all statements that accurately describe working with Development Spaces in SAP Business Application Studio for SAP HANA Cloud modeling.
The unit introduces SAP Business Application Studio (BAS), its use for SAP HANA Cloud development, and the concept of Development Spaces, including tooling selection and operational considerations.
Each developer can have multiple Development Spaces, but only one can run at a time; you must stop one before starting another.
The lesson states that only one development space can be running at a time and you must stop one to swap.
For HANA modeling, including the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor extension in the development space is essential.
The text explicitly calls this extension a key tool that must be included for modeling.
Development Spaces are the same as Cloud Foundry spaces and share the same lifecycle controls.
The content warns not to confuse development spaces with Cloud Foundry spaces.
After creation, you can freely rename a Development Space and change its kind of application.
It states that a development space’s name and kind of application cannot be changed after creation.
BAS does not rely on extensions; all modeling features are enabled by default.
BAS leverages extensions; key tools must be selected when creating the space.
Differentiate Development Spaces from Cloud Foundry spaces.
Recall which extension is called out as essential for HANA modeling.
Think ONE-at-a-time and ONE key extension: one running space; Calculation View Editor.

A and B align with the text: only one running Development Space at a time, and the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor is essential. C is incorrect due to the explicit warning not to equate Development Spaces with Cloud Foundry spaces. D is incorrect because name and kind cannot be changed post-creation. E is incorrect since BAS depends on extensions for tooling.
Which operational constraints might influence how you organize multiple Development Spaces?
A developer pauses their UI5 space to start a HANA modeling space that includes the Calculation View Editor.
When setting up a Development Space in SAP Business Application Studio for SAP HANA Cloud modeling, which choice aligns with the essential tool selection and environment behavior described?
Developers use Development Spaces in SAP Business Application Studio. For HANA Cloud modeling, specific extensions are needed, and only one development space can run at a time.
Include the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor extension; only one development space can run at a time.
The text states this extension is essential for HANA modeling and that only one development space can be running at once.
Rely on Cloud Foundry spaces since they are the same as development spaces.
The text warns not to confuse development spaces with Cloud Foundry spaces.
Skip installing extensions because BAS includes all HANA tools by default.
It explicitly says you must choose required tools (extensions); the HANA Calculation View Editor is essential.
Run multiple development spaces simultaneously to switch without stopping any.
The text indicates only one development space can be running at a time and you must stop one to swap.
Change the development space kind after creation to match HANA modeling needs.
The text notes a development space's name and kind cannot be changed after creation.
Recall which extension is called out as essential for HANA modeling.
Consider the rule about how many development spaces can run at the same time.
Think HANA CVE + single running space: one key tool, one active space.
HANA modeling requires the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor extension, and BAS allows only one development space to run at a time. Other options conflict with explicit cautions or constraints.
Why does the environment restrict you to a single running development space, and how does that influence your workflow planning?
When creating a new HANA modeling space, enable the Calculation View Editor and stop your current space before starting another.

The statement below is accurate according to the text: In SAP Business Application Studio, only one Development Space can be running at a time, and you must stop the current one before starting another.
Developers work in SAP Business Application Studio using Development Spaces. Tooling for SAP HANA Cloud modeling is added via extensions when creating a space.
True
False
Recall the operational constraint mentioned about running multiple Development Spaces simultaneously.
Do not confuse Development Spaces with Cloud Foundry spaces.
Think: One-at-a-time garage—only one car (space) runs at once.
True. The text states that only one Development Space can be running at a time, and you must stop the one you are using before swapping to another.
If your workflow needs another toolset, what step must you take before starting a different Development Space?
You stop a UI5-focused space before starting a HANA modeling space.
Select all statements that are accurate about SAP Business Application Studio (BAS) development spaces for HANA modeling.
BAS provides developer-specific environments composed of development spaces. For HANA modeling, certain extensions are required, and operational constraints apply when running spaces.
Each developer works in their own environment composed of one or more development spaces.
The text states that in BAS, each developer has their own environment made up of one or more development spaces.
A development space’s name and kind of application cannot be changed after creation.
The maintenance note specifies that once created, the name and kind of application cannot be changed.
Multiple development spaces can run concurrently to speed up modeling tasks.
The text says only one development space can be running at one time; you must stop one to start another.
For HANA modeling, including the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor extension in the development space is essential.
It explicitly states this extension is essential for HANA Cloud modeling.
Development spaces are the same as Cloud Foundry spaces and can be used interchangeably.
The text warns not to confuse development spaces with Cloud Foundry spaces, implying they are different.
Recall the constraint on how many development spaces can run at once.
Focus on what is described as essential for HANA modeling within a space.
Think ONE: one developer’s environment, one running space; and ONE essential extension for HANA views.

A, B, and D align with the text: developers have environments made of development spaces; name and kind cannot change post-creation; and the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor is essential. C is wrong because only one space can run at a time. E is wrong because development spaces are distinct from Cloud Foundry spaces.
How do the operational constraints of development spaces influence your workflow when switching projects?
A modeler stops their current development space before starting another configured with the Calculation View Editor.
In SAP Business Application Studio, which choice is essential to include when configuring a development space for SAP HANA Cloud modeling?

Developers create one or more development spaces and select required tools (extensions) for their tasks. Development spaces are distinct from Cloud Foundry spaces, and only one development space can run at a time.
SAP HANA Calculation View Editor extension
The text states this extension is essential for modeling in SAP HANA Cloud.
Cloud Foundry Space Manager extension
Cloud Foundry spaces are explicitly distinguished from development spaces; this extension is not cited as essential.
Generic Git Integration extension
While useful, Git is not identified in the text as essential for HANA modeling.
Start from Template Project Generator extension
The template wizard is mentioned, but not as an essential extension for HANA modeling.
Explorer Ribbon Customizer extension
The ribbon is described, but no such extension is named or required for modeling.
Focus on the tool explicitly called essential for modeling in SAP HANA Cloud.
Do not confuse development spaces with Cloud Foundry spaces when considering tools.
Model HANA? Choose the Calculation View Editor.
For HANA Cloud modeling, the SAP HANA Calculation View Editor must be included in the development space; other options are not identified as essential in the text.
Which other extensions might you add for your workflow, even if they are not marked essential here?
When setting up a new space for modeling, select the HANA Calculation View Editor so you can create calculation views.
The statement below is accurate according to the text.
“In SAP Business Application Studio, only one development space can be running at a time; to switch, you must stop the currently running space.”

Development spaces are the personal work environments within SAP Business Application Studio. Tooling (extensions) is selected per space, and space runtime behavior affects how you work across spaces.
True
False
Focus on what the text says about how many development spaces can run simultaneously.
Recall the step required before swapping between spaces.
One-at-a-time: think of a single active workspace engine running per developer space.
The text states that only one development space can be running at a time and you must stop the current one before switching.
If the statement were false, how would the process of switching between spaces differ?
You finish modeling in Space A, stop it, then start Space B to work on a different project.
Which actions align with importing and sharing development content in SAP Business Application Studio for SAP HANA Cloud? Select all that apply.
The lesson covers importing existing projects into SAP Business Application Studio workspaces and using Git to collaborate and share source code in SAP HANA Cloud projects.
Import a project from a .zip or .tar archive into your workspace.
The text states you can import a project into SAP Business Application Studio from a .zip or .tar archive.
Use Git to share development content and collaborate in parallel.
The text names Git as the preferred method for sharing development content and supporting collaborative, parallel work.
Rely on Web IDE as the recommended tool for SAP HANA Cloud data modeling.
The context points to SAP Business Application Studio, not Web IDE, in this setting.
Manage SAP HANA artifacts deployment directly from the Explorer view.
A listed item indicates Explorer is for listing files and folders; deployment management is not stated.
Clone from Git is unrelated to importing projects.
The context lists Clone from Git alongside Import as project start options; it is related to bringing projects in.
Look for operations explicitly mentioned as ways to bring projects into BAS.
Identify how the text describes collaboration and sharing among developers.
Think: Import via archives; Share via Git.

A and B reflect the stated import methods (.zip/.tar) and the role of Git for sharing and collaboration. C contradicts the emphasis on BAS. D overextends the Explorer’s role. E incorrectly separates cloning from importing.
Cite the specific phrases in the context that support A and B.
A developer downloads a .zip of a project to import into BAS and later uses Git to push changes for teammates.
In SAP Business Application Studio, what is the preferred method for sharing development content within an SAP HANA Cloud project?
The lesson discusses importing existing projects into SAP Business Application Studio and mentions approaches for collaborating and sharing development content among developers.
Using Git for source control and collaboration
The context states Git is the preferred method for sharing development content in an SAP HANA Cloud project.
Emailing project folders to teammates
Email-based sharing is not identified as the preferred approach in the context.
Uploading code snippets to chat channels
Chat uploads are not presented as the recommended method for project collaboration.
Using Web IDE transport requests
The context focuses on BAS and names Git as the preferred sharing method, not Web IDE transports.
Manually copying files via shared network drives
Manual file copying is not mentioned as the preferred collaboration method.
Focus on the tool highlighted for collaborative source control in development.
Eliminate options that are ad-hoc or manual rather than integrated with BAS workflows.
Think “Git for team fit” when sharing code in BAS projects.
The material explicitly identifies Git as the preferred method for sharing development content and collaborating in SAP HANA Cloud projects within BAS.
How does using Git improve parallel work compared to manual file sharing?
A team clones a shared repository into BAS, creates feature branches, and merges changes via pull requests.
The statement below is accurate according to the text: "Git is the preferred method for sharing development content in an SAP HANA Cloud project."
The text discusses importing projects into SAP Business Application Studio and mentions approaches for sharing development content within SAP HANA Cloud projects.
True
False
Locate the sentence that names a preferred method for sharing development content.
Focus on whether the text assigns preference, not just possibility.
Preferred in the text points to Git for sharing in SAP HANA Cloud projects.
The text explicitly states that Git is the preferred method for sharing development content in an SAP HANA Cloud project.
If the statement were false, what alternative would the text have needed to identify as preferred?
A team exports and imports code via Git to collaborate on an SAP HANA Cloud application.
Which actions align with importing and sharing projects in SAP Business Application Studio for SAP HANA Cloud?
The context discusses importing existing projects into SAP Business Application Studio and using Git as the preferred method for sharing development content in SAP HANA Cloud projects.
Import a project from a .zip or .tar archive into your workspace.
The text states you can import a project into SAP Business Application Studio from a .zip or .tar archive.
Use Git to collaborate with other developers and manage source code.
The text explains Git is used to manage source code and support collaboration and parallel work.
Rely on Web IDE as the recommended tool for data modeling in SAP HANA Cloud.
The provided items indicate SAP Business Application Studio is recommended for data modeling, not Web IDE.
Share development content primarily by emailing archives instead of using Git.
The text identifies Git as the preferred method for sharing development content.
Deploy SAP HANA artifacts directly from the Explorer view.
The listed capabilities for Explorer include listing files and folders; deployment management is not indicated there.
Focus on actions explicitly mentioned for importing and sharing in the workspace.
Recall which tool is stated as the preferred method for sharing development content.
ZIP/TAR for import; Git for share.

Importing can be done from .zip/.tar archives, and Git is preferred for sharing and collaboration. Web IDE and email-based sharing are not the recommended approaches per the text, and Explorer’s noted role is file/folder listing, not deployment.
Which phrases in the text indicate the preferred sharing method and supported import formats?
A developer imports a zipped project into BAS and then pushes updates to a shared Git repository for teammates.
Which option best describes why Git is used in SAP HANA Cloud projects?

The context discusses importing projects into SAP Business Application Studio and highlights Git as the preferred method for sharing development content and managing source code for collaborative work.
To manage source code and enable collaborative sharing of development content.
The text states Git is preferred for sharing development content and used to manage source code, supporting collaboration.
To deploy SAP HANA artifacts directly to the database.
Deployment of artifacts is not described as a Git function in the text.
To create projects from templates within the studio.
Templates are a separate studio feature; the text links Git to sharing and source control, not template creation.
To import .zip or .tar archives into the workspace.
Archive import is discussed separately; it is not presented as a Git capability.
To navigate the layout and features of the studio interface.
Navigation of the studio is unrelated to Git per the provided text.
Focus on what the text says Git is preferred for in SAP HANA Cloud projects.
Re-read the context and focus on key terms.
Git = share + manage code.
Git is described as the preferred method for sharing development content and for managing source code to support collaboration.
How do sharing and source control together support parallel work among developers?
Developers clone a repository to work in parallel and push changes to share updates.

The statement below is accurate according to the text.

“Git is the preferred method for sharing development content in an SAP HANA Cloud project.”
The lesson discusses importing existing projects into SAP Business Application Studio and describes how Git supports collaboration and sharing of development content in SAP HANA Cloud projects.
True
False
Look for wording about a “preferred method” for sharing development content.
Verify that the method mentioned aligns with SAP HANA Cloud project collaboration.
Preferred tool for sharing in HANA Cloud projects: think Git for teamwork.
The text states that Git is the preferred method for sharing development content in an SAP HANA Cloud project.
If the statement were false, which tool would the text need to name as the preferred method instead?
A team uses Git to import and export project content among developers in BAS.
Select all statements that align with the Unit 2 overview of SAP HANA Cloud calculation views.

This unit emphasizes creating dimension, cube, and time-based calculation views using the graphical editor, supported data sources, hierarchy usage for drill-down navigation, and validating outputs. Analytical applications can query views directly, while calculation views remain read-only.
You can define one or more hierarchies in calculation views to support drill-down navigation over large datasets.
The context states hierarchies represent structures (such as organization or time) and are used for easy drill-down; you can define one or more hierarchies in calculation views.
Calculation views in SAP HANA Cloud are read-only and do not change data in database tables.
Explicitly stated: calculation views are read only and cannot change data in the SAP HANA Cloud database.
Analytical applications must route all queries through the application server rather than accessing calculation views directly.
The text says analytical applications can bypass the application server and directly query calculation views.
Only cube calculation views can be created with the graphical calculation view editor; dimension and time-based views require scripting.
The unit states you will create dimension, cube, and time-based dimension calculation views using the graphical editor.
Calculation views routinely write calculated results back to source tables to optimize performance.
Contradicted by the statement that calculation views are read-only and cannot change data.
Identify which statements reflect read-only behavior and direct querying by analytical apps.
Recall which view types the unit says you will create using the graphical editor.
Think H: Hierarchies for drill-down; R: Read-only; G: Graphical editor for multiple view types.

A and B align with the unit: hierarchies support drill-down and calculation views are read-only. C, D, and E contradict the text about direct querying, graphical editor support, and non-writing behavior.
Explain how defining hierarchies would help an analytical app that directly queries a cube view.
An analyst explores a product hierarchy in a cube view, drilling from category to product while the app queries the view directly without persisting changes.
Which statement best characterizes calculation views in SAP HANA Cloud as presented in this unit?

The unit covers creating dimension, cube, and time-based calculation views with the graphical editor, supported data sources, hierarchies for drill-down navigation, and checking outputs to ensure correct results.
They are read-only models that can be queried directly by analytical applications to compute results on-the-fly.
The text states calculation views are read only and analytical apps can bypass the application server and directly query them where data is calculated on-the-fly.
They primarily serve as write-enabled interfaces for transactional updates to tables.
Contradicted by the text: calculation views are read only and cannot change data.
They must always be consumed via the application server and cannot be accessed directly.
The text says analytical applications can bypass the application server and query calculation views directly.
They are limited to hierarchical time structures and cannot model dimensions or cubes.
The unit explicitly includes creating dimension, cube, and time-based calculation views.
They cannot be consumed by ABAP-based applications under any circumstances.
The text provides ABAP as an example of consuming a calculation view.
Recall what the unit says about whether calculation views can modify data.
Focus on how analytical applications interact with calculation views according to the text.
Think ROAM: Read-Only, Accessed directly, On-the-fly, Modeling (dimension/cube/time).
The unit emphasizes that calculation views are read-only artifacts that analytical apps can query directly, with data computed on-the-fly in SAP HANA Cloud.
How does being read-only influence when you would choose a calculation view versus a transactional interface?
An analytics dashboard connects directly to a cube calculation view to drill down via hierarchies without writing any data.
Calculation views in SAP HANA Cloud are read-only and cannot change data in the database.

This unit covers creating dimension, cube, and time-based calculation views, supported data sources, and verifying outputs. It also introduces hierarchies for drill-down navigation in analytical scenarios.
True
False
Consider whether analytical queries typically modify underlying tables.
Look for explicit statements about write capabilities in the overview.
Think: Views are for viewing—calculation views calculate and expose results without writing back.
The text states that calculation views are read only and cannot change data in the SAP HANA Cloud database.
If the statement were false, what operations would a calculation view need to perform, and does the text support that?
An analytical app queries a cube calculation view for KPIs; the data is computed on-the-fly without writing to any tables.
Select all statements that align with the Unit 2 overview on calculation views in SAP HANA Cloud.
The unit outlines capabilities around creating different types of calculation views, supported data sources, output verification, hierarchy usage, and how applications may consume these views.
You can create dimension, cube, and time-based dimension calculation views using the graphical calculation view editor.
The unit specifies creation of dimension, cube, and time-based dimension calculation views via the graphical editor.
Calculation views are read-only and do not change data in the SAP HANA Cloud database.
The text states calculation views are read only and cannot change data.
Analytical applications must query calculation views through an application server layer; direct access is not possible.
The text says analytical applications can bypass the application server and directly query calculation views.
Hierarchies cannot be defined in calculation views; they must be modeled only in the source application.
The text notes you can define one or more hierarchies in calculation views for drill-down navigation.
ABAP applications cannot consume calculation views because they are only intended for internal database use.
The text provides the example that it is possible to consume a calculation view from ABAP.
Identify which statements reflect creation tasks versus consumption and data modification.
Look for mentions of direct access and hierarchy support in the overview.
DCT + RO: Dimension, Cube, Time-based via editor; Read-Only consumption possible directly.

The unit covers creating dimension, cube, and time-based views (A) and emphasizes calculation views are read-only (B). It also notes direct querying by analytical apps (contradicting C), support for defining hierarchies in calculation views (contradicting D), and that ABAP can consume calculation views (contradicting E).
Explain how defining hierarchies within a calculation view supports drill-down navigation for analytical applications.
An analytical dashboard connects directly to a cube calculation view with a defined time-based hierarchy to enable year-to-quarter drill-down without writing back to the database.
Which statement best describes how analytical applications can interact with calculation views in SAP HANA Cloud according to this unit?
This unit covers creating dimension, cube, and time-based calculation views using the graphical editor, supported data sources, checking outputs, and how applications can consume these views.
They can bypass the application server and directly query read-only calculation views where results are computed on-the-fly in-memory.
The text states analytical applications can directly query calculation views, which are read-only and computed on-the-fly in the in-memory database.
They must always go through the application server because calculation views cannot be accessed directly.
Contradicted by the text; direct querying that bypasses the application server is explicitly mentioned.
They can use calculation views to write aggregated results back to the database tables.
Incorrect; calculation views are read-only and cannot change data in the database.
They can only consume calculation views from ABAP, not from analytical applications.
The text gives ABAP as an example consumer but also states analytical applications can query calculation views directly.
They require a special write-enabled variant of calculation views to perform drill-down analysis.
No write-enabled variant is described; drill-down is supported via hierarchies, and calculation views remain read-only.
Recall whether the unit permits bypassing the application server for analytics.
Re-read the context and focus on key terms.
Think: Views are for viewing—read-only, computed in-memory.

Analytical applications can directly query calculation views in SAP HANA Cloud. These views are read-only and compute results on-the-fly in the in-memory database, enabling server bypass for analytics.
How does the read-only nature of calculation views influence application architecture choices?
An analytical dashboard directly queries a cube calculation view to display drill-down metrics without routing through an application server.
Calculation views in SAP HANA Cloud are read-only and cannot modify underlying database tables.
This unit covers creating dimension, cube, and time-based calculation views, supported data sources, checking outputs, and the role of hierarchies in drill-down navigation.
True
False
Consider how analytical applications interact with calculation views.
Recall whether the unit mentions any write operations from calculation views.
Think: Views are for viewing—read, not write.
The text states that calculation views are read only and cannot change data in the SAP HANA Cloud database.
If the statement were false, what specific capability would calculation views need to have?
An analytical app queries a cube calculation view to aggregate sales; no updates to tables occur via the view.
Select all statements that correctly describe Dimension Calculation Views.
Consider how these views handle master data, their output characteristics, and how they are reused alongside cube calculation views.
They expose master data and can combine sources, filters, calculated attributes, and hierarchies.
The text states that dimension calculation views expose master data, can combine multiple sources, define filters, calculate attributes, and create hierarchies.
Their output is attributes-only and lists individual values without aggregation.
The text explains they typically contain attributes, not measures, and produce a complete list of individual values rather than aggregated results.
They are mainly used for summing quantities across transactions.
Summations/aggregations are associated with cube calculation views; dimension views do not aggregate measures.
They cannot be reused across different cube calculation views.
The text emphasizes that dimension views are reusable and can be shared by several cube calculation views.
They are designed to replace cube calculation views in analytics scenarios.
The text indicates dimension views are consumed by cube calculation views, not a replacement for them.
Identify which statements emphasize master data exposure and attribute focus.
Differentiate between what dimensions do vs. what cubes do with measures.
DIM = Describe Information about Master data; CUBE = Calculate/aggregate.

A and B align with the text: dimension views expose master data, allow combining sources with filters/calculations/hierarchies, and output attributes-only without aggregation. C is incorrect because aggregation belongs to cubes. D is incorrect because dimensions are reusable across cubes. E is incorrect because dimensions are consumed by cubes, not replacements.
Explain how a product dimension could be shared between two different cube calculation views.
A Product dimension view (attributes like Product ID, Category, Hierarchy) is reused by both Sales Order and Purchase Order cube views to provide consistent product master data.
Which statement best describes a key characteristic of a dimension calculation view?
Dimension calculation views expose master data and can include filters, calculated attributes, and hierarchies. They are designed for reuse across multiple cube calculation views.
It provides attributes-only output listing individual values without aggregation.
The text states a dimension view is attributes-only and lists individual values, not aggregated measures.
It primarily calculates and stores summarized measures for reporting.
Summarized measures belong to cube calculation views, not dimensions.
It is intended to be consumed only by a single cube calculation view.
The text emphasizes reusability across several cube calculation views.
It prevents combining multiple data sources to ensure consistency.
The text explicitly allows combining multiple data sources in a dimension view.
It aggregates numerical quantities by default to reduce data volume.
The text says numerical values are listed individually and not aggregated in dimension views.
Recall how measures are treated differently in cube vs. dimension views.
Think about whether the view lists individual values or aggregates them.
Dimensions describe; cubes calculate.
Dimension calculation views are attributes-only, listing individual values without aggregation, and are designed for reuse across cubes.
Explain why a sales or purchase order cube would consume the same product dimension.
A product dimension view lists each product’s attributes; separate cubes for sales and purchasing both reference it.
The statement below is accurate according to the text.
“Dimension calculation views expose master data with attributes only and do not aggregate measures; they are typically reused by multiple cube calculation views.”
Consider what dimension calculation views are designed to expose, how their outputs behave regarding aggregation, and how they are consumed in modeling workflows.
True
False
Recall whether dimension views handle measures or focus on attributes.
Think about where aggregation typically happens in calculation views.
DIM = Data Item Master; CUBE = Calculations Bundle.
According to the text, dimension calculation views present master data as attributes without aggregating measures and are shared across multiple cube calculation views for reuse.
If the statement were false, what would need to change about aggregation or reuse to contradict the text?
A product dimension feeding both a purchase order cube and a sales order cube, providing consistent product attributes without aggregation.
Select ALL statements that correctly describe dimension calculation views in the context provided.

Dimension calculation views focus on master data exposure and can be combined, filtered, and extended with attributes and hierarchies. Consider how they differ from cube calculation views and how they are reused.
They expose master data and can include filters, calculated attributes, and hierarchies.
The text states that a dimension calculation view exposes master data, allows filters, calculates additional attributes, and creates hierarchies.
They are centralized, highly reusable objects that provide consistent data across consuming views.
The text describes dimension calculation views as highly-reusable, centralized objects providing consistent data.
They aggregate numerical values by default to produce totals for reporting.
The text specifies that dimensions list individual values and do NOT aggregate; aggregation belongs to cube calculation views.
They are typically consumed by cube calculation views, such as purchase order or sales order cubes.
The text gives the example of a product dimension used in both purchase order and sales order cube calculation views.
Their primary purpose is to model measures for analytical summations.
The text indicates dimensions are attributes-only (master data) and not for measures; summations are done in cube calculation views.
Differentiate between attribute-focused dimensions and measure-focused cubes.
Look for statements about reuse and consumption patterns across multiple cube views.
Think: DIM = Data Items of Master (attributes, not measures).

Dimensions expose master data with attributes, filters, calculations, and hierarchies (A), are centralized and reusable (B), and are consumed by cubes, e.g., purchase and sales order cubes (D). They do not aggregate by default (C incorrect) and are not for modeling measures (E incorrect).
Explain why a product dimension can be shared between purchase and sales order cubes without rework.
A Product dimension view lists each product with attributes and hierarchies; both Sales and Purchasing cubes link to it for consistent product data.
Which statement best describes the role of a dimension calculation view?
Consider what these views expose, how their output behaves with numerical values, and how they may be reused across models.
It exposes master data as attributes, listing individual values without aggregation, and is reused across multiple cube calculation views.
The text states dimension views expose master data, produce complete lists (no aggregation), and are reusable inputs to several cube views.
It primarily aggregates measures for reporting and cannot be reused by other views.
Aggregation of measures is the role of cube views, and dimension views are explicitly reusable.
It exposes transactional line items with pre-summed quantities to simplify analytics.
The context focuses on master data and no aggregation; pre-summed quantities contradict the description.
It creates measures from attributes to enable automatic summarization in reporting tools.
Dimension views are attributes-only; creating measures and summarization align with cube views.
It prevents sharing of product information across different cube calculation views to enforce isolation.
The text emphasizes sharing/reuse, e.g., a product dimension used in both purchase and sales order cubes.
Recall whether dimension views handle measures or attributes.
Think about if quantities are aggregated or listed individually in the output.
Consider how a product dimension might be used by multiple cubes.
Dimension = Data dictionary: attributes only, dependable, and reusable.

Dimension calculation views expose master data as attributes, output individual records without aggregation, and are designed for reuse by multiple cube calculation views (e.g., product dimension shared by purchase and sales order cubes).
Describe a scenario where a shared dimension view reduces duplication across cube models.
A Product dimension view joins product tables, adds hierarchies, and is consumed by both Sales and Purchasing cubes.
The statement below is accurate according to the text.
"Dimension calculation views list individual attribute values without aggregating numerical fields, and are commonly reused across multiple cube calculation views."
Consider what a dimension calculation view exposes, how it treats numerical data, and how it is consumed by cube calculation views.
True
False
Check whether dimension views perform aggregation or simply expose attribute rows.
Recall the relationship: dimensions supply shared master data to cubes.
DIM = Details In Master-data; CUBE = Calculate/aggregate.

Per the text, dimension calculation views expose master data as attributes, listing values individually (no aggregation). They are reusable and shared across multiple cube calculation views that require the same master data.
If the statement were false, how would you change it—would you claim that dimensions aggregate or that they are not reused by cubes?
A product dimension provides product attributes to both a purchase order cube and a sales order cube without aggregating product data.
Select all statements that align with the behavior and structure of cube calculation views as described.

The lesson discusses creating cube calculation views that include measures, sourcing columns from multiple tables, and extending cubes with a star join to bring in additional attributes from dimension calculation views, including handling shared column naming via aliases.
A calculation view of type cube is used when the model includes measures.
The text states that when you want a calculation view that includes measures, you use a view of type cube.
A cube can source columns from different database tables, such as sales and returns, within one model.
An example given describes a cube calculation view for orders accessing columns from both Sales and Returns tables.
In a CUBE with star join, shared columns’ Name and Label can be freely changed directly on the shared columns.
The text says Name and Label properties of shared columns cannot be changed; only Alias Name and Alias Label can be defined.
Providing Alias Names is mandatory when column names conflict across joined dimension views or with private columns.
The text explicitly notes aliasing is mandatory in case of name conflicts among underlying dimension views or private columns.
A star join prevents you from hiding any columns; all brought-in attributes must remain visible.
The text indicates you can hide some columns to keep only those needed, even with a star join.
Identify which statements directly reflect the described capabilities of cube views and star joins.
Watch for wording about what cannot be changed versus what can be aliased.
Cube with measures; star join for more attributes; alias to resolve conflicts.

A, B, and D are supported: cube includes measures; cubes can pull from multiple tables; alias names are mandatory when conflicts occur. C is wrong because shared column Name/Label cannot be changed; E is wrong because columns can be hidden.

Analytic privileges filter calculation view data per user based on attribute values, supporting row-level access without duplicating views. Some restriction types can be converted to others in one direction only, and object access must still be granted separately.
They enable per-user data filtering on calculation views using attribute-based restrictions.

The text states the conversion from Attribute to SQL Expression is possible, but the reverse is not.
